metadata.case_name: Man Mohan Chawla v. J.S. Sethi

facts.text: Man Mohan Chawla was tenant since before 1958 in premises in Delhi belonging to J.S. Sethi. Contractual rent Rs. 160 per month.

Sethi filed petition under s.14(1) of Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 for ejectment against Chawla for default in paying rent for seven months consecutively. Chawla deposited rent claimed pursuant to Rent Controller direction, amount paid to Sethi, proceeding disposed of.
Chawla committed default for three consecutive months. Sethi commenced another proceeding under s.14(1) for ejectment.
Chawla denied default, pleaded sent Rs.320 by postal money order to Sethi on March 19, 1963 which Sethi refused. Sethi denied money order tendered to him.
Chawla pleaded contractual rent excessive, standard rent should not exceed Rs.50 per month, prayed standard rent be fixed by Controller.
Controller rejected contentions, passed order of ejectment. Confirmed in appeal by Rent Control Tribunal. Second appeal to Delhi High Court unsuccessful, judgment dated January 24, 1969.
Evidence: Postal receipt for Rs.320 to Sethi, but did not bear residential address of Sethi. Sethi deposed no one tendered money order. Testimony believed by all courts.
Chawla made deposit of rent for three months in proceeding, but plea not raised before Controller or Tribunal, first before High Court, not entertained.

legal_issues.text: Whether Controller bound to determine standard rent in ejectment proceeding under s.14(1) when tenant pleads contractual rent exceeds standard rent, despite limitation under s.12.
Whether courts erred in holding Chawla could not obtain benefit of s.14(2) of Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958.
Whether legal presumption from despatch of postal money order ignored.
Whether deposit of rent for three months means not in arrears for three consecutive months.

petitioner_arguments.text: Controller bound to determine standard rent in proceeding instituted by Sethi, failure makes ejectment order illegal.
Courts below erred in holding Chawla could not obtain benefit of s.14(2).
Legal presumption arising from despatch of postal money order for Rs.320 ignored by courts.
Chawla deposited rent for three months, not in arrears for three consecutive months.
s.12 limitation applies only to substantive applications, not defence in ejectment petition. Dispute under s.15(3) includes standard rent.

respondent_arguments.text: Denied postal money order sent by Chawla was tendered to him.

court_reasoning.text: Contentions iii and iv fail: no proof of money order tendered and refused; deposit plea not raised earlier, depends on unproved facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only postal receipt without address; Sethi testimony believed.

court_reasoning.text: Standard rent determined only by Controller under s.9; until fixed, contractual rent payable. Prohibition in ss.4,5 operates post-determination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of Act: Controller alone fixes standard rent; s.12 limitation applies even to defence plea in ejectment.

court_reasoning.text: s.15(3) dispute is about contractual rent, not standard rent; interim rent fixed till standard rent in separate s.12 proceeding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No power under s.15(3) to fix standard rent in ejectment; limitation s.12 applies.

court_reasoning.text: High Court cases distinguishing standard rent fixation in ejectment overruled; difference from prior Act noted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.12 limitation not nugatory; tenant cannot evade by defence plea.

court_reasoning.text: Chawla not entitled to s.14(2) benefit: prior default, obtained benefit in first proceeding by deposit; no payment/deposit in second.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso to s.14(2) bars second benefit; proceeding disposed after deposit is benefit obtained.

holdings.text: Controller not bound to fix standard rent in ejectment proceeding if s.12 limitation barred; must be separate application.
Tenant who previously obtained s.14(2) benefit by deposit in prior proceeding not entitled again after second default.
No presumption from mere despatch of money order without proof of tender and refusal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jiwan Industries Private Ltd. v. Santosh Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Held Controller can fix standard rent in ejectment even after dismissal; disagreed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs Suraj Balram Sawhney Sons. v. Dr. D. Kiri
precedents_cited.relevance: Controller jurisdiction under s.15(3) to fix standard rent in ejectment despite s.12 bar; disagreed.

precedents_cited.case_name: S.K. Chatterjee and Anr. v. J.N. Ghoshal
precedents_cited.relevance: s.15(3) dispute includes standard rent claim; disagreed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chander Bhan v. Nand Lal and Anr.
precedents_cited.relevance: Two provisions for standard rent: s.9/s.12 and s.15(3); disagreed, renders s.12 nugatory.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lala Manohar Lal Nathan Mal v. Madan Lal Murari Lal
precedents_cited.relevance: Under prior Act, standard rent fixable in ejectment; phraseology differs in 1958 Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Radhey Piari v. S. Kalyan Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Under prior Act, standard rent fixable in ejectment proceeding.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs ejectment for non-payment, standard rent fixation, limitation, interim rent, protection against eviction.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed. Ejectment order by Controller confirmed by Tribunal and High Court upheld. Tenant failed to prove money order tender, standard rent plea barred by limitation, not entitled to s.14(2) benefit after prior default.

key_quotes.text: "Under the scheme of the Act standard rent of a given tenement is that amount only which the Controller determines. Until the standard rent is fixed by the Controller the contract between the landlord and the tenant determines the liability of the tenant to pay rent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on when standard rent binds.

key_quotes.text: "The prohibition against recovery of rent in excess of the standard rent applies only from the date on which the standard rent is determined by order of the Controller and not before that date."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If in a proceeding under s.14(1)(a) the tenant raises by way of defence a contention that the standard rent be determined the Controller may treat that as an application under s.12 and deal with it according to law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
